summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary, sworn interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General with Federal Bureau of Prisons employee Michael Thomas on June 17, 2021. The interview concerns Thomas's alleged misconduct related to his duties at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, including false statements, job performance failure, security failure, and reporting false information, specifically in the context of the period surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein. Thomas provides detailed testimony about his work history, training, duties in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), his interactions with Epstein, the events of August 9-10, 2019, and his discovery of Epstein's body.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Incident
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with an orange homemade rope; he was placed on suicide watch. He claimed his cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione tried to harm him.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU
events.description: Epstein was returned from suicide watch/psychological observation back to the SHU. He was reportedly assigned a new cellmate, Angel Quiles.

events.title: Cellmate Removed
events.description: Inmate Angel Quiles was removed from the MCC, leaving Jeffrey Epstein without a cellmate.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's Death
events.description: Michael Thomas discovered Jeffrey Epstein hanging in his SHU cell at approximately 6:33 a.m. Thomas ripped him down, called for help, and initiated CPR. Epstein was pronounced dead.

events.title: OIG Interview of Michael Thomas
events.description: DOJ OIG conducts a sworn, voluntary interview with BOP employee Michael Thomas regarding his alleged misconduct and actions surrounding Epstein's death.

locations: Law Offices of (location redacted), 17 Academy Street, Suite 305, Newark, New Jersey (interview location)
keyFacts: Michael Thomas admitted that he and Tova Noel did not conduct any of the required inmate counts or rounds during their shift on August 10, 2019, prior to discovering Epstein, and falsified the related paperwork.

Thomas stated he was not informed by anyone (psychologists, supervisors, etc.) that Epstein was required to have a cellmate after coming off suicide watch, and he never saw any posted sign or email to that effect.

Thomas discovered Epstein hanging by a sheet/shirt from his bunk, ripped it down, and performed chest compressions. He believed Epstein died by suicide and denied any involvement or knowledge of foul play.
Thomas confirmed that no one could have entered the SHU or Epstein's cell without his or Noel's knowledge, as they controlled access and he did not recall anyone entering.
Thomas admitted that prior to August 10, 2019, there were times he certified that counts and rounds were conducted when they were not, though he claimed it was not a regular occurrence.
